alfredsnippet.snippet:
(cont'd)

"... Yet a mathematical theory is a closed system of thought. Its inferences are potentially present in the assumptions made at the start, and if the assumptions are mistaken, incomplete or otherwise inadequate, however ingenious and correct the mathematical methods used, the outcome will be wrong, partial or otherwise inadequate. Worse, this may not be directly apparent.

As that ponderous but robust pillar of English common sense, Dr. Samuel Johnson, has said, 'there can be no security in the consequences when the premises are not understood' -- and very often they are not."
alfredsnippet.name: Phys.org Post - The Problems of Specialization and Mathematics - Part 2
